awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Social Cybersecurity: Applying Social Influence to Improve Cybersecurity
awd_abstract_narration:
Research on the human factors of cybersecurity often treats people as isolated individuals rather than as social actors within a web of relationships and social influences. This project leverages known social influence principles such as making public commitments and social proof (i.e., people tend to copy others' behavior, especially when in doubt) to develop techniques that improve cybersecurity behavior and enhance security tool adoption.  The team will design, develop, and deploy examples of the use of social influence in three common contexts: standalone security training materials, real-time training ("micro-interventions") given at the moment of a security-related decision, and adoption of security tools and updates.  The work will deepen our knowledge of how to incorporate social influences into interface designs that improve people's security sensitivity, that is, the awareness, knowledge, and motivation to be secure.  It will also add to the toolbox of cybersecurity researchers and practitioners designing human-facing security tools, and raise public awareness through outreach efforts and widely deploying the security training mini-games.  Finally, the project will provide educational opportunities for a number of PhD and undergraduate students, both in doing the research and through integrating the research work and products into courses on human-computer interaction and security.

The project uses a number of well-known social influence mechanisms to influence security behavior, including reciprocity, social proof, consistency and commitment, liking, authority, and scarcity, through three main research thrusts.  The first thrust will develop standalone security training though security related mini-games.  The games will allow the researchers to control the observability of others' behaviors and deploy interface features and messages informed by social influence processes. In experiments, the research team will compare how emphasizing different influence processes affect people's security awareness, knowledge and behavior both immediately after the experiment and two weeks later.  The second thrust will develop micro-interventions in the context of login pages, based on preliminary work showing this is the most common time people think about security.  Working with their institution's information security office, the team will embed security training in system login pages. They will evaluate effectiveness of the training using logged user behavior and a one-month follow-up survey and interview.  The third thrust will encourage adoption of new security tools, behaviors, and updates by varying the social influence mechanisms used at different points in the adoption curve of a new tool.  Again, the team will run field studies in conjunction with their institution's information security office, measuring relative effectiveness of messages employing different social influence processes based on time-to-update.  Experimental materials, monitoring and analysis software, the mini-games themselves, and (when not creating security and privacy risks) the datasets themselves will be released publicly.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Our research into the human factors of cybersecurity focuses on people as social actors whose security behaviors are influenced by their relationships, communities and life situations. In this project we leveraged insights from social psychology and other fields to develop novel interventions and strategies for nudging adoption of expert-recommended tools and practices, such as using multi-factor authentication, creating unique passwords and regularly updating software. Our project had three main areas of work: 1) empirical research on security attitudes, behaviors, and adoption strategies, 2) design of security mini-games [fig. 1-3], and 3) design of everyday interventions to encourage better security practices [fig. 4-5]. 


In our empirical research on adoption strategies we introduced new ways to measure people’s attitudes towards security behaviors. We used these measures to collect data to understand why people resist adopting security tools and social influences on adoption. We described six steps of cybersecurity tool adoption and found that adoption decisions were influenced by trialability, troubleshooting support, authority influences (mandates, adoption leadership, caretaking) and peer/media influences (advice on password managers, exposure to news of others’ security breach experiences). Our findings help move the field of usable security away from “one size fits all” strategies by providing a basis and a method for segmenting the audience for security interventions and directing resources to those most likely to benefit.


We examined when and how people share digital account information like logins and passwords in romantic relationships and in the workplace. We found that romantic account sharing was influenced by relationship milestones and the couple’s social environment, which changes at different stages of a relationship. We also found that couples use account sharing to support collaboration. In our study of account sharing in the workplace, we found that account sharing supported basic information sharing needs of groups. 


In our work on the design of security mini-games, we applied theory from social psychology to develop games for increasing people’s belief they are capable of adopting and using cybersecurity protection measures and increasing their awareness of cybersecurity threats online.  We introduced the Hacked Time [fig. 1] and CALYPSO [fig. 2-3] games which use design techniques to enhance players' feelings of their ability to use security tools and increase their awareness of privacy and security threats. Our games bridge the gap between theory, design, and evaluation of transformational games in cybersecurity to encourage better privacy and security behaviors. 

In our work on everyday interventions we designed, developed, and deployed examples of the use of social influence in the adoption of security tools and updates. We developed a browser extension for providing security information and assessing compliance with needed security behavior change and conducted a study to test the effectiveness of social influence and reflective writing on security behavior [fig. 4]. Finally, we designed and developed a mobile application that uses social influences to encourage daily adoption of better privacy and security behaviors. In the application people enroll in a time bounded challenge and are presented with daily challenges they must complete [fig 5, left] and report on to a set of buddies within the application [fig. 5, right]. 

The results of our project deepen our knowledge of how to incorporate social influences into interface designs that improve people's security sensitivity, that is, the awareness, knowledge, and motivation to be secure. Our measures of security attitudes support research on differences in security-related intentions and behaviors. Our game development activities extend the literature on games for behavior change and cybersecurity awareness and intervention techniques. Our research into social influence elements of our everyday interventions contribute to the literature on behavior change interventions in cybersecurity. Our results suggest that non-personal sources of social influence (such as strangers) can be quite effective in swaying user's decisions to be more secure – however that effect can be canceled out when combined with other interventions such as reflective writing. Our games, browser extension and mobile application raise public awareness through outreach and provide a foundation for conducting future experiments on the effectiveness of social influences on cybersecurity tool adoption. 

Over the course of this project we published 15 peer-reviewed papers describing our research, one PhD thesis, and 4 additional publications and presented our results at relevant conferences and workshops. Our results are available on our project webpage here: https://socialcybersecurity.org/. We created an online version of the SA-6 instrument so researchers could easily utilize it in their work and provide links to all our research publications and game prototypes. Finally our project provided educational opportunities for a number of PhD, masters and undergraduate students, both in doing the research and through integrating the research work and products into our courses on human-computer interaction and security.

 


Last Modified: 04/14/2023
Modified by: Laura Dabbish

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1. Hacked Time game screen - Guided practice on how to set up a password manager which should increase the player�s feeling of their own ability to use this tool outside of the game.
    Tianying Chen
    Creative Commons
    Laura Dabbish
    Hacked Time game screen showing the player setting up a password manager.
  • Figure 2. CALYPSO game screen - An example of how we implemented the concept of �guided practice� in-game, in this case covering the process of email encryption. The player configures this feature themself as part of the narrative, led step by step through the process in-game.
    Isadora Krsek
    Creative Commons
    Laura Dabbish
    CALYPSO game screen where the player is setting up encrypted email as part of the game activity.
  • Figure 3. An example of how we implemented the concept of �guided practice� in-game in CALYPSO covering the process of downloading a secured password manager. The player configures this feature as part of the narrative, led step by step through the process in-game.
    Isadora Krsek
    Creative Commons
    Laura Dabbish
    CALYPSO game screen where the player is setting up a secure password manager as part of a game activity.
  • Figure 4. Safesea browser extension design for providing feedback on user privacy settings.
    Isadora Krsek
    Creative Commons
    Laura Dabbish
    Safesea browser extension design for providing feedback on user privacy settings.
  • Figure 5. Adulting101 security intervention mobile application - an example of a security daily challenge (left), and accountability buddies (right).
    Isadora Krsek
    Creative Commons
    Laura Dabbish
    Adulting101 security intervention mobile application which presents users with daily challenges shown on left side in a mobile phone screenshot and accountability buddies shown on the right side in a mobile phone screenshot.
